The move aims to equip students with essential AI literacy, prepare the workforce for future tech-driven jobs, and position India as a global AI hub.

Significant discrepancies exist between NMC figures and state medical council registrations, raising concerns about accurate healthcare planning and potentially misleading Parliament.

Nobel Peace winner Maria Machado: A democracy activist forced to live in hiding
description: Venezuelan opposition leader Maria Corina Machado has been awarded the Nobel Peace Prize for her unwavering commitment to democratic rights and her fight for a democratic transition in Venezuela.  Despite facing a ban from public office, Machado's primary victory highlighted widespread support for her vision of liberal economic reforms and a collective struggle for change.

title: Amitabh Bachchan keeps promise: Bengal man gets Rs 2L washroom after plea from KBC hot seat
description: Amitabh Bachchan fulfilled his promise to KBC 16 contestant Jayanta Duley by funding the construction of a bathroom for his family.  The 22-year-old sister, Shikha, expressed immense gratitude, stating the gesture preserved women's dignity by ending the embarrassment of bathing in the village pond. This personal intervention highlights Bachchan's commitment to addressing real-life sanitation issues.

title: Horoscope Today for October 11, 2025: Key Astrological Trends Affecting Gemini, Capricorn, Libra, Leo, and Other Zodiac Signs
On Diwali, ‘green crackers’ set to return with a bang
description: The Supreme Court is poised to permit the sale and use of green firecrackers in Delhi and NCR for Diwali, Gurupurav, and Christmas. While reserving orders, the bench questioned the necessity of a complete ban, noting no significant increase in pollution attributed to crackers. The government proposed strict measures, including a ban on series crackers and online sales, to ensure only approved green crackers are available.

title: Eight Indians, 10 firms face US sanctions over Iran oil link
description: America has sanctioned eight Indian individuals and ten companies. These actions are due to their involvement in trading Iranian oil. The US state department and treasury targeted numerous entities globally. Several Indian firms are accused of importing Iranian-origin petrochemicals and LPG. These shipments were destined for China and Pakistan. The sanctions highlight ongoing efforts to curb Iran's oil trade.

title: Chennai ragpicker tied to pole, beaten to death for alleged theft; body dumped in canal
description: A 26-year-old ragpicker met a brutal end near Red Hills, allegedly beaten to death by workers at a plastic chair manufacturing unit. Caught stealing scrap, he was tied to a pole and assaulted with rods before his body was found in a canal. Relatives protested, demanding justice. Police have registered a murder case against the owner and a worker.

title: Pondicherry University students lathicharged, arrested for protesting #MeToo by faculty
Ground Boeing 787s, demands pilots’ body
description: An Air India Boeing 787 diverted to Dubai due to a technical snag, with its autopilot system failing. This follows another incident last week where a Dreamliner's ram air turbine deployed on approach. The Federation of Indian Pilots has urged the grounding of all B787s amid continuous electrical issues and called for a special audit of Air India's aircraft maintenance.

title: 'Indians' success in US no conspiracy': Zoho's Sridhar Vembu
description: Zoho CEO Sridhar Vembu explains why Indian professionals dominate American technology leadership, attributing it to unintended consequences of the H-1B visa and green card system. The lengthy immigration process made job switching risky, creating committed long-term employees who naturally earned promotions. Vembu emphasises R&D success requires time-intensive commitment, not just funding. His comments come amid controversy over Trump's proposed $100,000 H-1B fee.

title: Microsoft engineer quits after 13 years; sends resignation email to employees
description: A senior Microsoft engineer has resigned protesting the company's cloud contracts with the Israeli military. Scott Sutfin-Glowski cited enabling potential atrocities as his reason for leaving. This follows months of internal dissent and employee firings over Gaza-related demonstrations. Microsoft previously stopped some services to an Israeli intelligence unit after a report. However, many contracts remain active, and employee protests continue. Activists demand a complete cut of ties with Israel.
